8.text:
This week I've been doing quite a lot of research
on the Isle of Portland

11.text:
on the south coast of England
and I discovered that the first Viking raid

17.text:
which was reported in the Anglo Saxon Chronicles
was reported to have taken place in the year

23.text:
789AD
and that's the first recorded Viking raid

26.text:
that we know about in England.
So that's been really really interesting.

29.text:
It's a place that I spent a lot of time
as a child

33.text:
living on the south coast of England
and interestingly is almost directly across

38.text:
from Alderney
but on the other side of the water

42.text:
and during the Viking Age
this was actually part of the Kingdom of Wessex.

46.text:
And it's also a place that I learnt about
during my geography lessons at school

49.text:
because it's the classical example of
a tombolo

53.text:
or a tombolo I'm never sure how to pronounce
those

56.text:
and is the kind of classical thing that you
learn about in your geography lessons.

61.text:
Particularly Chesil Beach.
So its been really exciting this week to find

65.text:
out a little more about that part of the British
coastline

70.text:
and might just be the first place that I start
my expedition from

74.text:
having learnt a little more about it.
And according to the Anglo Saxon Chronicle

78.text:
we know that three ships came over from Hordaland
in Norway

82.text:
or what would be today Norway
and I don't quite know what happened

88.text:
I've
I, in researching I've come across two different

91.text:
versions
The first is that the three ships were lost

96.text:
at sea
they were travelling and they got blown off

101.text:
on the Isle of Portland by mistake
without planning to come there

106.text:
and the second is that it was a planned raid.
So I'm not really sure what the truth is

111.text:
those are the two versions.
But essentially

115.text:
the Viking people arrived
they had actually been trading with Britain

119.text:
for
a number of years very peacefully

122.text:
so this is the first known actual raid or
attack

126.text:
and as they arrived on the Isle of Portland
they were met by the local tax men

131.text:
who tried to encourage them to go to Dorchester
I think

137.text:
and to go and pay the taxes for trading
but the Vikings refused

141.text:
and ended up killing the tax guys instead.
Now having sailed around the coast with the

147.text:
Royal Navy before
and from stories of other sailors

151.text:
I wouldn't be surprised if it is true that
the Vikings got

155.text:
washed ashore
because you do get some very strange

159.text:
weather and currents around that area
so it wouldn't surprise me one little bit

164.text:
if they did end up there by mistake
especially in those days as well

169.text:
without all the technology that we have today.
In fact there is actually a special boat called

173.text:
the Lerret Boat
which was designed by the local fishermen

176.text:
who fished on Chesil Beach and they designed
this special boat

180.text:
to actually cope with the conditions of the
weather and the local

184.text:
kind of
geological and geographical conditions as

187.text:
well.
And this week I drew a picture of the Lerret

192.text:
Boat
for my students and for my book

195.text:
which you can see there.
That is the Lerret Boat.

200.text:
And this was built by the fishermen around
1615AD.

205.text:
And it was designed to cope with the steep
shingle bank and the local weather conditions.

209.text:
And it is quite unusual compared to most boats
but actually not compared to the Viking boats.

215.text:
Because it can be rowed from either side
so you could pull the boat in one way

220.text:
and then pull it back out which is something
the Vikings did

223.text:
so that they could make a quick getaway.
And it also has no row locks to hold the oars

230.text:
but it does have these special
hole pins

234.text:
and it is generally rowed by four people
and the oars are a lot thinner

238.text:
than you would find on other boats
so I found this very interesting

240.text:
particularly as I'm going to be building my
boat as well.

245.text:
And the Lerret boat would also have a fifth
person

247.text:
who would be in charge of the steering and
also pulling in the fishing nets

252.text:
so I found that really interesting this week.
There is my picture of it there

256.text:
that is the Lerret Boat.
And all of these pictures I make are available

Teachers Pay Teachers
which is part of my fundraising for the boat

and if you are one of the patrons then

and you'll get one free to download every

and I'm planning to put these in a book

a kind of a colouring book

the Isle of Portland
the local boat building

and I've been learning about the quarries

301.text:
so it's something that's
Portland is very famous for

304.text:
it's actually mostly limestone
and the limestone rock

309.text:
Portland Rock is used all around the world
but you will actually find it on things like

316.text:
and St Paul's Cathedral
so it's pretty famous

319.text:
and the quarries still work today as well.
And one of the interesting things I found

324.text:
out was that there's a superstition on the
Isle of Portland

327.text:
about rabbits and you shouldn't ever talk
about rabbits

330.text:
because the local people get quite upset
and I think that this superstition comes from

338.text:
when people have been working in the quarries
before the quarries have collapsed

342.text:
or there has been a rock fall
the last thing they have seen are rabbits

346.text:
so
perhaps where there are rabbit burrows or

350.text:
rabbit warrens
and these big tunnels so that is why the ground

354.text:
has caved in
so it's a bit of a local superstition.

357.text:
Which I'm interested in finding out more about
and I'm also really excited because Portland

365.text:
when I fly over to Alderney
one of the things that I see as I fly over

369.text:
which is really iconic
is this big red and white

373.text:
lighthouse
which is one of the things I'm really looking

375.text:
forward to seeing
actually from the sea

378.text:
and I didn't realise that Portland had
originally three lighthouses

384.text:
but the other two
don't work now

388.text:
which is the red and white one
that you see from the air

391.text:
is automated now.
But people wanted to have a lighthouse there

396.text:
for quite a long time
way before the Romans were there and

403.text:
before they had lighthouses
people would actually light fires to help

407.text:
around the coastline
because it was quite dangerous

410.text:
and then this one guy called Sir John Clayton
he wanted to build a lighthouse there

415.text:
in about 1669 I think it was
and he was told that he couldn't build it

420.text:
because it would
just be too expensive

421.text:
so he had been petitioning for a lighthouse
for a long, long time.

425.text:
But they didn't get one until
about 1903

428.text:
between 1903-1905
Portland Bill was finally built so

432.text:
it has made quite a big difference I think
to the safety

436.text:
and is certainly one of the things people look for
particularly sailors

439.text:
when they are racing around the coastline
so

442.text:
it is one of the things I am really looking
forward to seeing

445.text:
and is just so iconic.
But the Isle of Portland also has a very strong

449.text:
Roman connection
and the Romans called it Vindelis

453.text:
and I think this is a term that is still used
by the local people as well.

458.text:
And the other very interesting thing I found
out about Portland is that there are 32 places

463.text:
in the world
with the name Portland

466.text:
and all of them I think apart from 1 are named
after this particular Portland

471.text:
so Portland in Oregon is one example
that's in America

475.text:
and that is named after Portland in England.
And the only one that isn't named after Portland

482.text:
is named after the Duke of Portland
and that is in New Zealand

486.text:
and it only has one person living there.
So it has been quite good fun learning about

some new places this week.
